First, if it\'s your first landing, aim for the light side of the Mun. The dark side is a pain to land on, though I have done it myself. It\'s just harder to judge the latter stages of the landing.

Basically, always try to have a bit of spare fuel, just in case. No more than one small spare tank, though, otherwise it gets too heavy. You may want to try the stop and drop method. Once you get to about 60km above the Munar surface, click the little window displaying speed to calibrate it for surface. This means that it takes into account the Mun\'s rotation. Burn retrograde until your velocity is just about zero. This basically tries to control both descent speed and velocity relative to the surface at the same time, so that when you do the final descent, you won\'t end up flying sideways into a hill. Once you\'ve done this, reorient so that your ship is facing straight up, engines pointing downwards. Turn SAS on. It\'s a good idea to have ASAS so you needn\'t worry too much about keeping the craft oriented properly. You will need RCS if you want to fine-tune your horizontal movement so you don\'t snap off any lander legs as you touch down.

Then, wait until you get to around 20km up. You should still have your engines pointed directly down. Burn until your velocity is less than 50m/s. This allows you to keep the speed manageable, so you don\'t end up flying into the surface at 500m/s despite having full thrust. Then, wait once more. Wait until you\'re about 8km up. Then, burn again until you\'re going at less than 40m/s. Once you hit the 40m/s mark, adjust your thrust so you\'re just slowly decreasing your speed. Decrease speed at around 0.2m/s every few seconds. If you get below 10m/s while still a fair way off the ground, kill the throttle until you\'re up to around 25m/s again.

Note that almost all of the Mun\'s surface will be above the 0m on the altitude meter. Some places get up to around 2,500m, so beware. Start a very controlled descent (keep your velocity between 2m/s and 10m/s) around 3,500m. Lower your landing gear.

If your retrograde indicator is not directly upwards (the little dot in the very center of the blue region of the navball), make sure your rocket is oriented towards that dot, and activate RCS. Here\'s where you need it. By this point, the velocity meter should read 'surface', if you haven\'t bothered to change it yourself. Using the RCS translation controls (by default, I,J,K,L) to get your retrograde velocity indicator pointing directly up. The left and right (J and L) affect the indicator in reverse (using the Left -- J -- makes it move right and vice versa) whilst the forward/back (think of them as up/down on the navball) are not reversed. It\'s a bit confusing, but not difficult once you get the hang of it. Keep an eye on your velocity through this.

Once you start noticing the terrain coming up slowly around you (it is REALLY noticeable, btw), then prepare to slow down below 3m/s. Stay below 3m/s if you can, cutting throttle if necessary to avoid going back up again. Any speed under 6m/s is pretty safe, but under 4m/s is ideal.

Good luck!

Personally, I really don\'t like the stop-high-and-descend-straight method. There are too many ways to screw it up as you descend and descend and descend. Some of us like to bring periapsis down to about 3000m (on Mun), brake hard, and then bring remaining lateral speed to zero just by backwards-steering toward the retrograde marker. I don\'t want to muck with lateral RCS while I\'m already trying to steer, throttle, and watch terrain; it\'s just too many buttons to be mashing all at once. But I do use RCS at the last second, to brake from around 10m/s to 5 or less. I cut throttle about 1 ship-length from actual touchdown to prevent that *$^%! ship-killing bounce that the springy landing legs are prone to, and float down like a feather on RCS pulses, which are much more fine-controllable and responsive than the lagging throttle.

I was having a lot of trouble with crashing too, so I built this lander. It\'s bigger than most players\' landers because I made it low and wide to prevent tipping over. I put the legs on hardpoints so they\'d stick down far enough to prevent the engines from hitting the ground, and it can break off up to 3 legs and still come to rest in flyable condition. It\'s got more engines and fuel than it needs, but I figured it would be good practice for the time when we need bigger ships to deliver actual cargoes and stuff. And it can easily fly home from either moon. Hope this helps.

Here is how I normally land:

1. Get in a low orbit around the Mun 5000 meters is ideal

2. Choose a landing spot

3. Burn retrograde until yor path hits where you want to land. Overshoot it a bit.

4. When you near your landing spot start buring to kill horizontal velocity.

5. Once you slow down enough and are ready for landing keep your speed below 12 m/s

6. Below 10m/s is even better

Hope I helped!
